Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: A routine, optional daily prayer service is scheduled.
Story:
The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my taxi crawling along the icy road. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch and muttering about missing his international flight. I could feel his anxiety pressing on me, urging me to drive faster, to somehow beat the storm and get him to the airport on time. But every time I considered speeding up, the car slid a little, reminding me of my duty to keep us both safe.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the daily prayer service at the church was about to begin. As the priest, I was expected to lead the prayers, to be a steady presence for my small congregation, even if today’s service was routine and optional. I imagined the handful of faithful waiting in the quiet sanctuary, expecting my calm guidance. Torn between the urgent needs of my passenger and the quiet expectations of my parishioners, I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
